 On April 12 , 2015 , Freddie Carlos Gray , Jr. , a 25-year-old black man , was arrested by the Baltimore Police Department for possessing what the police alleged was an illegal knife under Baltimore law .While being transported in a police van , Gray fell into a coma and was taken to a trauma center .Gray died on April 19 , 2015 ; his death was ascribed to injuries to his spinal cord .On April 21 , 2015 , pending an investigation of the incident , six Baltimore police officers were suspended with pay .The circumstances of the injuries were initially unclear ; eyewitness accounts suggested that the officers involved used unnecessary force against Gray during the arrest—a claim denied by all officers involved .Commissioner Anthony W. Batts reported that , contrary to department policy , the officers did not secure him inside the van while driving to the police station ; this policy had been put into effect six days prior to Gray 's arrest , following review of other transport-related injuries sustained during police custody in the city , and elsewhere in the country during the preceding years .The medical investigation found that Gray had sustained the injuries while in transport .The medical examiner 's office concluded that Gray 's death could not be ruled an accident , and was instead a homicide , because officers failed to follow safety procedures `` through acts of omission . ''

data.expected_output: On May 1 , 2015 , the Baltimore City State 's Attorney , Marilyn Mosby , announced her office had filed charges against six police officers after the medical examiner 's report ruled Gray 's death a homicide .The prosecutors stated that they had probable cause to file criminal charges against the six police officers who were believed to be involved in his death .The officer driving the van was charged with second-degree `` depraved-heart '' murder for his indifference to the considerable risk that Gray might be killed , and others were charged with crimes ranging from manslaughter to illegal arrest .On May 21 , a grand jury indicted the officers on most of the original charges filed by Mosby with the exception of the charges of illegal imprisonment and false arrest , and added charges of reckless endangerment to all the officers involved .Gray 's hospitalization and subsequent death resulted in an ongoing series of protests .On April 25 , 2015 , a major protest in downtown Baltimore turned violent , resulting in 34 arrests and injuries to 15 police officers .After Gray 's funeral on April 27 , civil disorder intensified with looting and burning of local businesses and a CVS drug store , culminating with a state of emergency declaration by Governor Larry Hogan , Maryland National Guard deployment to Baltimore , and the establishment of a curfew .

#### Generated Context
 The Thirty Years ' War was a war fought primarily in Central Europe between 1618 and 1648 .One of the most destructive conflicts in human history , it resulted in eight million fatalities not only from military engagements but also from violence , famine , and plague .Casualties were overwhelmingly and disproportionately inhabitants of the Holy Roman Empire , most of the rest being battle deaths from various foreign armies .The deadly clashes ravaged Europe ; 20 percent of the total population of Germany died during the conflict and there were losses up to 50 percent in a corridor between Pomerania and the Black Forest .In terms of proportional German casualties and destruction , it was surpassed only by the period January to May 1945 ; one of its enduring results was 19th-century Pan-Germanism , when it served as an example of the dangers of a divided Germany and became a key justification for the 1871 creation of the German Empire ( although it excluded the German-speaking parts of the Austro-Hungarian Habsburg empire ) .Initially a war between various Protestant and Catholic states in the fragmented Holy Roman Empire , it gradually developed into a more general conflict involving most of the European great powers .These states employed relatively large mercenary armies , and the war became less about religion and more of a continuation of the France–Habsburg rivalry for European political pre-eminence .The war was preceded by the election of the new Hapsburg Holy Roman Emperor , Ferdinand II , who tried to impose religious uniformity on his domains , forcing Roman Catholicism on its peoples .The northern Protestant states , angered by the violation of their rights to religious liberty , which had been granted in the Peace of Augsburg , banded together to form the Protestant Union .Ferdinand II was a devout Roman Catholic and much less tolerant than his predecessor , Rudolf II , who ruled from the largely Protestant city of Prague .Ferdinand 's policies were considered strongly pro-Catholic and anti-Protestant .These events caused widespread fears throughout northern and central Europe , and triggered the Protestant Bohemians living in the then relatively loose dominion of Habsburg Austria ( and also with the Holy Roman Empire ) to revolt against their nominal ruler , Ferdinand II .
data.expected_output: After the so-called Defenestration of Prague deposed the Emperor 's representatives in Prague , the Protestant estates and Catholic Habsburgs started gathering allies for war .The Protestant Bohemians ousted the Habsburgs and elected the Calvinist Frederick V , Elector of the Rhenish Palatinate as the new king of the Kingdom of Bohemia .Frederick took the offer without the support of the Protestant Union .The southern states , mainly Roman Catholic , were angered by this .Led by Bavaria , these states formed the Catholic League to expel Frederick in support of the Emperor .The Empire soon crushed the perceived Protestant rebellion in the Battle of White Mountain , executing leading Bohemian aristocrats shortly after .Protestant rulers across Europe unanimously condemned the Emperor 's action .After the atrocities committed in Bohemia , Saxony finally gave its support to the Protestant Union and decided to fight back .Sweden , at the time a rising military power , soon intervened in 1630 under its king Gustavus Adolphus , transforming what had been simply the Emperor 's attempt to curb the Protestant states into a full-scale war in Europe .

#### Generated Context
 The Second Battle of the Aisne ( or , 16 April – mid-May 1917 ) was the main part of the Nivelle Offensive , a Franco-British attempt to inflict a decisive defeat on the German armies in France .The Entente strategy was to conduct offensives from north to south , beginning with an attack by the British Expeditionary Force ( BEF ) then the main attack by two French army groups on the Aisne .General Robert Nivelle planned the offensive in December 1916 , after he replaced Joseph Joffre as Commander-in-Chief of the French Army .The objective of the attack on the Aisne was to capture the prominent , east–west ridge of the Chemin des Dames , north-east of Paris and then advance northwards to capture the city of Laon .When the French armies met the British advancing from the Arras front , the Germans would be pursued towards Belgium and the German frontier .The offensive began on 9 April , when the British began the Battle of Arras .On 16 April , the ( GAR , Reserve Army Group ) attacked the Chemin des Dames and the next day , the Fourth Army , part of ( GAC , Central Army Group ) , near Reims to the south-east , began the Battle of the Hills .

data.expected_output: The Chemin des Dames ridge had been quarried for stone for centuries , leaving a warren of caves and tunnels which were used as shelters by German troops to escape the French bombardment .The offensive met massed German machine-gun and artillery fire , which inflicted many casualties and repulsed the French infantry at many points .The French achieved a substantial tactical success and took but failed to defeat decisively the German armies .The failure had a traumatic effect on the morale of the French army and many divisions mutinied .Nivelle was superseded by General Philippe Pétain , who adopted a strategy of `` healing and defence '' , to resume the wearing-out of the German Army while conserving French infantry .

 The Indo-Pakistani War of 1965 was a culmination of skirmishes that took place between April 1965 and September 1965 between Pakistan and India .The conflict began following Pakistan 's Operation Gibraltar , which was designed to infiltrate forces into Jammu and Kashmir to precipitate an insurgency against Indian rule .India retaliated by launching a full-scale military attack on West Pakistan .the unk war caused thousands of casualties on both sides and witnessed the largest engagement of armored vehicles and the largest tank battle since world war ii .Hostilities between the two countries ended after a United Nations-mandated ceasefire was declared following diplomatic intervention by the Soviet Union and the United States , and the subsequent issuance of the Tashkent Declaration .Much of the war was fought by the countries ' land forces in Kashmir and along the border between India and Pakistan .

#### Generated Context
 Hurricane Ingrid was one of two tropical cyclones , along with Hurricane Manuel , to strike Mexico within a 24‑hour period , the first such occurrence since 1958 .Ingrid was the ninth named storm and second hurricane of the 2013 Atlantic hurricane season .It formed on September 12 in the Gulf of Mexico from a broad disturbance that also spawned Manuel in the eastern Pacific .After initially moving westward toward Veracruz , Ingrid turned northeastward away from the coast .Favorable conditions allowed it to attain hurricane status on September 14 , and the next day Ingrid attained peak winds of 140 km/h ( 85 mph ) .Subsequently , increased wind shear weakened the convection as the storm turned more to the northwest and west .On September 16 , Ingrid made landfall just south of La Pesca , Tamaulipas in northeastern Mexico as a strong tropical storm , and dissipated the next day .
data.expected_output: The hurricane was also the last one to form in the Gulf of Mexico until Hurricane Hermine in 2016 .The combined impacts of hurricanes Ingrid and Manuel affected two-thirds of Mexico , killing 192 people and causing MXN $ 75 billion , or roughly US $ 5.7 billion in damage .Most of the effects were due to Manuel , though Ingrid was directly responsible for at least 32 deaths and $ 20 billion ( MXN , US $ 1.5 billion ) in damage .The two storms precipitated of water , the equivalent of filling every dam in Mexico .Rainfall from the storm peaked at in Tuxpan , Veracruz .

data.actual_output: The Thirty Years' War, which was primarily fought in Central Europe between 1618 and 1648, was one of the most destructive conflicts in human history. It resulted in eight million fatalities, not only from military engagements but also from violence, famine, and plague. Casualties were overwhelmingly and disproportionately inhabitants of the Holy Roman Empire, most of the rest being battle deaths from various foreign armies. The deadly clashes ravaged Europe; 20 percent of the total population of Germany died during the conflict, and there were losses up to 50 percent in a corridor between Pomerania and the Black Forest. In terms of proportional German casualties and destruction, it was surpassed only by the period January to May 1945. One of its enduring results was 19th-century Pan-Germanism, when it served as an example of the dangers of a divided Germany and became a key justification for the 1871 creation of the German Empire (although it excluded the German-speaking parts of the Austro-Hungarian Habsburg empire). Initially a war between various Protestant and Catholic states in the fragmented Holy Roman Empire, it gradually developed into a more general conflict involving most of the European great powers. These states employed relatively large mercenary armies, and the war became less about religion and more of a continuation of the France–Habsburg rivalry for European political pre-eminence. The war was preceded by the election of the new Hapsburg Holy Roman Emperor, Ferdinand II, who tried to impose religious uniformity on his domains, forcing Roman Catholicism on its peoples. The northern Protestant states, angered by the violation of their rights to religious liberty, which had been granted in the Peace of Augsburg, banded together to form the Protestant Union. Ferdinand II was a devout Roman Catholic and much less tolerant than his predecessor, Rudolf II, who ruled from the largely Protestant city of Prague. Ferdinand's policies were considered strongly pro-Catholic and anti-Protestant. data.actual_output:
The Second Battle of the Aisne, also known as the Battle of the Hills, was a major engagement of the Nivelle Offensive, a Franco-British attempt to inflict a decisive defeat on the German armies in France during World War I. The battle took place between 16 April and mid-May 1917, with the French Fourth Army launching an attack on the Chemin des Dames ridge, east of Paris. The objective was to capture the ridge and advance northwards to capture the city of Laon.

The battle began with a massive barrage by the French, which was followed by an infantry assault. However, the German defenses proved formidable, with massed machine-gun and artillery fire inflicting heavy casualties on the French infantry. Despite fierce fighting, the French were ultimately repulsed from the ridge.

The battle was a failure for the French, as it resulted in a traumatic effect on the morale of the French army. Philippe Pétain, the French commander, adopted a strategy of "healing and defence" to conserve the resources of the French infantry and wear out the German Army. Meanwhile, the Germans used caves on the Chemin des Dames ridge as escape routes from the French bombardment.

The Second Battle of the Aisne was a resumption of the fighting on the Aisne front, which had been relatively quiet since the First Battle of the Aisne in 1914. The battle marked the end of the Nivelle Offensive, which had failed to achieve its objectives.
data.expected_output: The Chemin des Dames ridge had been quarried for stone for centuries , leaving a warren of caves and tunnels which were used as shelters by German troops to escape the French bombardment .The offensive met massed German machine-gun and artillery fire , which inflicted many casualties and repulsed the French infantry at many points .The French achieved a substantial tactical success and took but failed to defeat decisively the German armies .The failure had a traumatic effect on the morale of the French army and many divisions mutinied .Nivelle was superseded by General Philippe Pétain , who adopted a strategy of `` healing and defence '' , to resume the wearing-out of the German Army while conserving French infantry .

data.actual_output:
The Indo-Pakistani War of 1965 was a military conflict between India and Pakistan that lasted from April to September 1965. The war began after Pakistan's Operation Gibraltar, which aimed to infiltrate forces into the state of Jammu and Kashmir to foment an insurrection against Indian rule. India retaliated by launching a full-scale military attack on West Pakistan.

The war caused thousands of casualties on both sides and witnessed the largest engagement of armored vehicles and the largest tank battle since World War II. Hostilities between the two countries ended after a United Nations-mandated ceasefire was declared following diplomatic intervention by the Soviet Union and the United States, and the subsequent issuance of the Tashkent Declaration. Much of the war was fought by the countries' land forces in Kashmir and along the border between India and Pakistan.

During the war, India amassed troops and resources in Kashmir, while Pakistan received meaningful support from other countries. The war resulted in a strategic and political defeat for Pakistan, which was seen as a consequence of its attempt to gain control over Kashmir. The war also highlighted the need for a peaceful resolution to the dispute over Kashmir, which continues to this day.
data.expected_output: This war saw the largest amassing of troops in Kashmir since the Partition of India in 1947 , a number that was overshadowed only during the 2001–2002 military standoff between India and Pakistan .Most of the battles were fought by opposing infantry and armoured units , with substantial backing from air forces , and naval operations .Many details of this war , like those of other Indo-Pakistani Wars , remain unclear .India had the upper hand over Pakistan when the ceasefire was declared .although the two countries fought to a standoff , the conflict is seen as a strategic and political defeat for pakistan , as it had neither succeeded in fomenting insurrection in kashmir nor had it been able to gain meaningful support at an international level .

This is a comprehensive timeline of the events surrounding the death of Freddie Gray in Baltimore, Maryland, in April 2015. Gray was arrested by the Baltimore Police Department for possessing what the police alleged was an illegal knife under Baltimore law. While being transported in a police van, Gray fell into a coma and was taken to a trauma center. Gray died on April 19, 2015; his death was ascribed to injuries to his spinal cord. On April 21, 2015, pending an investigation of the incident, six Baltimore police officers were suspended with pay. The circumstances of the injuries were initially unclear; eyewitness accounts suggested that the officers involved used unnecessary force against Gray during the arrest—a claim denied by all officers involved. Commissioner Anthony W. Batts reported that, contrary to department policy, the officers did not secure him inside the van while driving to the police station; this policy had been put into effect six days prior to Gray's arrest, following review of other transport-related injuries sustained during police custody in the city, and elsewhere in the country during the preceding years. The medical investigation found that Gray had sustained the injuries while in transport. The medical examiner's office concluded that Gray's death could not be ruled an accident, and was instead a homicide, because officers failed to follow safety procedures "through acts of omission."

#### Generated Context
 The Thirty Years ' War was a war fought primarily in Central Europe between 1618 and 1648 .One of the most destructive conflicts in human history , it resulted in eight million fatalities not only from military engagements but also from violence , famine , and plague .Casualties were overwhelmingly and disproportionately inhabitants of the Holy Roman Empire , most of the rest being battle deaths from various foreign armies .The deadly clashes ravaged Europe ; 20 percent of the total population of Germany died during the conflict and there were losses up to 50 percent in a corridor between Pomerania and the Black Forest .In terms of proportional German casualties and destruction , it was surpassed only by the period January to May 1945 ; one of its enduring results was 19th-century Pan-Germanism , when it served as an example of the dangers of a divided Germany and became a key justification for the 1871 creation of the German Empire ( although it excluded the German-speaking parts of the Austro-Hungarian Habsburg empire ) .Initially a war between various Protestant and Catholic states in the fragmented Holy Roman Empire , it gradually developed into a more general conflict involving most of the European great powers .These states employed relatively large mercenary armies , and the war became less about religion and more of a continuation of the France–Habsburg rivalry for European political pre-eminence .The war was preceded by the election of the new Hapsburg Holy Roman Emperor , Ferdinand II , who tried to impose religious uniformity on his domains , forcing Roman Catholicism on its peoples .The northern Protestant states , angered by the violation of their rights to religious liberty , which had been granted in the Peace of Augsburg , banded together to form the Protestant Union .Ferdinand II was a devout Roman Catholic and much less tolerant than his predecessor , Rudolf II , who ruled from the largely Protestant city of Prague .Ferdinand 's policies were considered strongly pro-Catholic and anti-Protestant .These events caused widespread fears throughout northern and central Europe , and triggered the Protestant Bohemians living in the then relatively loose dominion of Habsburg Austria ( and also with the Holy Roman Empire ) to revolt against their nominal ruler , Ferdinand II .
data.actual_output: The Thirty Years' War was a conflict that took place in Central Europe from 1618 to 1648. It was a devastating war, resulting in an estimated eight million fatalities, with most of the casualties being inhabitants of the Holy Roman Empire.The war began as a conflict between various Protestant and Catholic states in the fragmented Holy Roman Empire, but it gradually developed into a more general conflict involving most of the European great powers.The conflict was sparked by the election of Ferdinand II, a devout Roman Catholic and more hostile towards Protestantism than his predecessor, Rudolf II.Ferdinand's policies were considered strongly pro-Catholic and anti-Protestant, causing widespread fears and revolt among the Protestant populations in northern and central Europe.The war, which was initially focused on religious conflict, gradually became a struggle for power and dominance among the European great powers.Throughout the conflict, various armies engaged in battle, and the toll on human life was immense.The Thirty Years' War left a lasting impact on Europe, with its enduring results including 19th-century Pan-Germanism, which served as an example of the dangers of a divided Germany and became a key justification for the creation of the German Empire in 1871.
data.expected_output: After the so-called Defenestration of Prague deposed the Emperor 's representatives in Prague , the Protestant estates and Catholic Habsburgs started gathering allies for war .The Protestant Bohemians ousted the Habsburgs and elected the Calvinist Frederick V , Elector of the Rhenish Palatinate as the new king of the Kingdom of Bohemia .Frederick took the offer without the support of the Protestant Union .The southern states , mainly Roman Catholic , were angered by this .Led by Bavaria , these states formed the Catholic League to expel Frederick in support of the Emperor .The Empire soon crushed the perceived Protestant rebellion in the Battle of White Mountain , executing leading Bohemian aristocrats shortly after .Protestant rulers across Europe unanimously condemned the Emperor 's action .After the atrocities committed in Bohemia , Saxony finally gave its support to the Protestant Union and decided to fight back .Sweden , at the time a rising military power , soon intervened in 1630 under its king Gustavus Adolphus , transforming what had been simply the Emperor 's attempt to curb the Protestant states into a full-scale war in Europe .

#### Generated Context
 The Second Battle of the Aisne ( or , 16 April – mid-May 1917 ) was the main part of the Nivelle Offensive , a Franco-British attempt to inflict a decisive defeat on the German armies in France .The Entente strategy was to conduct offensives from north to south , beginning with an attack by the British Expeditionary Force ( BEF ) then the main attack by two French army groups on the Aisne .General Robert Nivelle planned the offensive in December 1916 , after he replaced Joseph Joffre as Commander-in-Chief of the French Army .The objective of the attack on the Aisne was to capture the prominent , east–west ridge of the Chemin des Dames , north-east of Paris and then advance northwards to capture the city of Laon .When the French armies met the British advancing from the Arras front , the Germans would be pursued towards Belgium and the German frontier .The offensive began on 9 April , when the British began the Battle of Arras .On 16 April , the ( GAR , Reserve Army Group ) attacked the Chemin des Dames and the next day , the Fourth Army , part of ( GAC , Central Army Group ) , near Reims to the south-east , began the Battle of the Hills .
data.actual_output: The French Fourth Army met with determined resistance from German forces, resulting in heavy casualties and a temporary stalemate.In an attempt to break the deadlock, French General Philippe Pétain adopted a strategy of "healing and defense", conserving his infantry and using caves along the Chemin des Dames ridge as escape routes from the German machine-gun and artillery fire.This strategy eventually led to the defeat of the Germans and the capture of the Chemin des Dames ridge, but the traumatic effect on the French morale was significant and the battle is often seen as a turning point in the war.After the Battle of the Hills, the French army resumed its attack on the Chemin des Dames ridge, this time led by General Pétain's new strategy of "healing and defense".This continued until mid-May, when the Germans were forced to retreat from the Chemin des Dames ridge.The Second Battle of the Aisne was a major failure for the French army, but it was also a turning point in the war, as it marked the beginning of General Pétain's strategy of "healing and defense" and its success in defeating the Germans.
data.expected_output: The Chemin des Dames ridge had been quarried for stone for centuries , leaving a warren of caves and tunnels which were used as shelters by German troops to escape the French bombardment .The offensive met massed German machine-gun and artillery fire , which inflicted many casualties and repulsed the French infantry at many points .The French achieved a substantial tactical success and took but failed to defeat decisively the German armies .The failure had a traumatic effect on the morale of the French army and many divisions mutinied .Nivelle was superseded by General Philippe Pétain , who adopted a strategy of `` healing and defence '' , to resume the wearing-out of the German Army while conserving French infantry .

data.actual_output:
The Indo-Pakistani War of 1965 was a major military conflict that took place between April and September 1965 between India and Pakistan. The war began after Pakistan launched Operation Gibraltar, a plan to infiltrate forces into Jammu and Kashmir to foment an insurgency against Indian rule. India retaliated by launching a full-scale military attack on West Pakistan.

The war caused thousands of casualties on both sides and saw the largest engagement of armored vehicles and the largest tank battle since World War II. The battle was fought mainly along the borders of India and Pakistan in Kashmir and along the border between the two countries. Despite the heavy fighting, the war ended with a United Nations-mandated ceasefire following diplomatic intervention by the Soviet Union and the United States, and the subsequent issuance of the Tashkent Declaration.

The war was a strategic and political defeat for Pakistan, as it failed to achieve its objectives of securing Kashmir. However, it did lead to increased military ties and coordination between India and the Soviet Union, which would later contribute to the Sino-Indian War of 1962. The war also highlighted the growing tension between India and Pakistan, which would lead to further conflicts, including the 1971 Indo-Pakistani War and the current standoff in Kashmir.

 On April 12 , 2015 , Freddie Carlos Gray , Jr. , a 25-year-old black man , was arrested by the Baltimore Police Department for possessing what the police alleged was an illegal knife under Baltimore law .While being transported in a police van , Gray fell into a coma and was taken to a trauma center .Gray died on April 19 , 2015 ; his death was ascribed to injuries to his spinal cord .On April 21 , 2015 , pending an investigation of the incident , six Baltimore police officers were suspended with pay .The circumstances of the injuries were initially unclear ; eyewitness accounts suggested that the officers involved used unnecessary force against Gray during the arrest—a claim denied by all officers involved .Commissioner Anthony W. Batts reported that , contrary to department policy , the officers did not secure him inside the van while driving to the police station ; this policy had been put into effect six days prior to Gray 's arrest , following review of other transport-related injuries sustained during police custody in the city , and elsewhere in the country during the preceding years .The medical investigation found that Gray had sustained the injuries while in transport .The medical examiner 's office concluded that Gray 's death could not be ruled an accident , and was instead a homicide , because officers failed to follow safety procedures `` through acts of omission . ''
data.expected_output: On May 1 , 2015 , the Baltimore City State 's Attorney , Marilyn Mosby , announced her office had filed charges against six police officers after the medical examiner 's report ruled Gray 's death a homicide .The prosecutors stated that they had probable cause to file criminal charges against the six police officers who were believed to be involved in his death .The officer driving the van was charged with second-degree `` depraved-heart '' murder for his indifference to the considerable risk that Gray might be killed , and others were charged with crimes ranging from manslaughter to illegal arrest .On May 21 , a grand jury indicted the officers on most of the original charges filed by Mosby with the exception of the charges of illegal imprisonment and false arrest , and added charges of reckless endangerment to all the officers involved .Gray 's hospitalization and subsequent death resulted in an ongoing series of protests .On April 25 , 2015 , a major protest in downtown Baltimore turned violent , resulting in 34 arrests and injuries to 15 police officers .After Gray 's funeral on April 27 , civil disorder intensified with looting and burning of local businesses and a CVS drug store , culminating with a state of emergency declaration by Governor Larry Hogan , Maryland National Guard deployment to Baltimore , and the establishment of a curfew .

#### Generated Context
 The Thirty Years ' War was a war fought primarily in Central Europe between 1618 and 1648 .One of the most destructive conflicts in human history , it resulted in eight million fatalities not only from military engagements but also from violence , famine , and plague .Casualties were overwhelmingly and disproportionately inhabitants of the Holy Roman Empire , most of the rest being battle deaths from various foreign armies .The deadly clashes ravaged Europe ; 20 percent of the total population of Germany died during the conflict and there were losses up to 50 percent in a corridor between Pomerania and the Black Forest .In terms of proportional German casualties and destruction , it was surpassed only by the period January to May 1945 ; one of its enduring results was 19th-century Pan-Germanism , when it served as an example of the dangers of a divided Germany and became a key justification for the 1871 creation of the German Empire ( although it excluded the German-speaking parts of the Austro-Hungarian Habsburg empire ) .Initially a war between various Protestant and Catholic states in the fragmented Holy Roman Empire , it gradually developed into a more general conflict involving most of the European great powers .These states employed relatively large mercenary armies , and the war became less about religion and more of a continuation of the France–Habsburg rivalry for European political pre-eminence .The war was preceded by the election of the new Hapsburg Holy Roman Emperor , Ferdinand II , who tried to impose religious uniformity on his domains , forcing Roman Catholicism on its peoples .The northern Protestant states , angered by the violation of their rights to religious liberty , which had been granted in the Peace of Augsburg , banded together to form the Protestant Union .Ferdinand II was a devout Roman Catholic and much less tolerant than his predecessor , Rudolf II , who ruled from the largely Protestant city of Prague .Ferdinand 's policies were considered strongly pro-Catholic and anti-Protestant .These events caused widespread fears throughout northern and central Europe , and triggered the Protestant Bohemians living in the then relatively loose dominion of Habsburg Austria ( and also with the Holy Roman Empire ) to revolt against their nominal ruler , Ferdinand II .
data.actual_output: The Thirty Years' War was a global catastrophe that ravaged Central and Northern Europe from 1618 to 1648. It was one of the deadliest wars in human history, resulting in an estimated eight million deaths from military action, famine, and disease. The conflict pitted a wide array of European powers against one another, primarily between Protestant and Catholic states. The war was sparked by a dispute within the Holy Roman Empire over the religious policies of the Hapsburg rulers.When the Protestant Bohemian estates revolted against their ruler, the Habsburg Emperor Ferdinand II, they were joined by the Protestant states of Northern Germany, who saw the revolt as an opportunity to undermine Habsburg control. The struggle turned into a full-fledged war as the Catholic League, led by the Jesuits, came to the defense of the Hapsburg Empire. The war also involved France, Sweden, and various other European states with their own geopolitical agendas.The Thirty Years' War was a long struggle over religious and political control, with the Protestants fighting to maintain their freedoms and the Catholics seeking to impose Catholicism on the territories under their dominion. The war was marked by numerous atrocities, including the Siege of Prague, the devastating Battle of White Mountain, and the famous Defenestration of Prague, which involved the expulsion of the Emperor's officials from the city. The fall of Prague significantly weakened the Protestant cause and allowed the Emperor Ferdinand to consolidate his power.The war was a significant setback for the emerging nation-state system, as it weakened the Holy Roman Empire and paved the way for the rise of the sovereign nation-state. The devastation and political chaos in Central Europe during the Thirty Years' War had an impact on the development of the continent for the next few centuries.
data.expected_output: After the so-called Defenestration of Prague deposed the Emperor 's representatives in Prague , the Protestant estates and Catholic Habsburgs started gathering allies for war .The Protestant Bohemians ousted the Habsburgs and elected the Calvinist Frederick V , Elector of the Rhenish Palatinate as the new king of the Kingdom of Bohemia .Frederick took the offer without the support of the Protestant Union .The southern states , mainly Roman Catholic , were angered by this .Led by Bavaria , these states formed the Catholic League to expel Frederick in support of the Emperor .The Empire soon crushed the perceived Protestant rebellion in the Battle of White Mountain , executing leading Bohemian aristocrats shortly after .Protestant rulers across Europe unanimously condemned the Emperor 's action .After the atrocities committed in Bohemia , Saxony finally gave its support to the Protestant Union and decided to fight back .Sweden , at the time a rising military power , soon intervened in 1630 under its king Gustavus Adolphus , transforming what had been simply the Emperor 's attempt to curb the Protestant states into a full-scale war in Europe .

data.actual_output:
Here is the complete text with all the events provided:

On April 12, 2015, Freddie Carlos Gray, Jr., a 25-year-old black man, was arrested by the Baltimore Police Department for possessing what the police alleged was an illegal knife under Baltimore law. While being transported in a police van, Gray fell into a coma and was taken to a trauma center. Gray died on April 19, 2015; his death was ascribed to injuries to his spinal cord.

On April 21, 2015, pending an investigation of the incident, six Baltimore police officers were suspended with pay. The circumstances of the injuries were initially unclear; eyewitness accounts suggested that the officers involved used unnecessary force against Gray during the arrest—a claim denied by all officers involved.

Commissioner Anthony W. Batts reported that, contrary to department policy, the officers did not secure him inside the van while driving to the police station; this policy had been put into effect six days prior to Gray's arrest, following review of other transport-related injuries sustained during police custody in the city, and elsewhere in the country during the preceding years. The medical investigation found that Gray had sustained the injuries while in transport.

The medical examiner's office concluded that Gray's death could not be ruled an accident, and was instead a homicide, because officers failed to follow safety procedures "through acts of omission."

On April 22, 2015, Marilyn Mosby, the State's Attorney for Baltimore City, announced that she had filed charges against the six police officers involved in Gray's arrest and transport. The charges included murder, manslaughter, and reckless endangerment.

On April 23, 2015, a grand jury indicted the officers on charges of reckless endangerment, and added additional charges of manslaughter and murder.

On April 25, 2015, a protest in downtown Baltimore turned violent, with 15 police officers injured and 34 arrests made. The protests were sparked by Gray's hospitalization and the subsequent charges filed against the officers.

On April 27, 2015, the medical examiner's office ruled Gray's death a homicide caused by a severe spinal injury.

On April 28, 2015, a funeral was held for Freddie Carlos Gray, Jr. in Baltimore.

On April 29, 2015, Governor Larry Hogan declared a state of emergency in Baltimore and deployed the Maryland National Guard to the city. The state of emergency was due to the ongoing civil disorder and looting that had occurred in the city since Gray's death.

On May 1, 2015, the Baltimore City Police Department announced that they had completed their investigation into Gray's death and had turned over their findings to the state's attorney's office.

On May 2, 2015, a report was released by the Baltimore City Police Department detailing the events surrounding Gray's arrest and transport. The report concluded that the officers involved had failed to follow department policies and procedures, which led to Gray's injuries and death.

On May 4, 2015, a trial was held for the six police officers charged in connection with Gray's death. The trial was ongoing as of the date of the report.

On May 11, 2015, the Baltimore City Police Department announced that it had implemented new policies and procedures for transporting prisoners in police vans, in response to Gray's death.

On May 18, 2015, the trial of the six police officers charged in connection with Gray's death concluded with all six officers being acquitted of all charges. The acquittal sparked widespread protests and civil unrest in Baltimore, with many protesters claiming that justice had not been served.
data.expected_output: On May 1 , 2015 , the Baltimore City State 's Attorney , Marilyn Mosby , announced her office had filed charges against six police officers after the medical examiner 's report ruled Gray 's death a homicide .The prosecutors stated that they had probable cause to file criminal charges against the six police officers who were believed to be involved in his death .The officer driving the van was charged with second-degree `` depraved-heart '' murder for his indifference to the considerable risk that Gray might be killed , and others were charged with crimes ranging from manslaughter to illegal arrest .On May 21 , a grand jury indicted the officers on most of the original charges filed by Mosby with the exception of the charges of illegal imprisonment and false arrest , and added charges of reckless endangerment to all the officers involved .Gray 's hospitalization and subsequent death resulted in an ongoing series of protests .On April 25 , 2015 , a major protest in downtown Baltimore turned violent , resulting in 34 arrests and injuries to 15 police officers .After Gray 's funeral on April 27 , civil disorder intensified with looting and burning of local businesses and a CVS drug store , culminating with a state of emergency declaration by Governor Larry Hogan , Maryland National Guard deployment to Baltimore , and the establishment of a curfew .

#### Generated Context
 The Thirty Years ' War was a war fought primarily in Central Europe between 1618 and 1648 .One of the most destructive conflicts in human history , it resulted in eight million fatalities not only from military engagements but also from violence , famine , and plague .Casualties were overwhelmingly and disproportionately inhabitants of the Holy Roman Empire , most of the rest being battle deaths from various foreign armies .The deadly clashes ravaged Europe ; 20 percent of the total population of Germany died during the conflict and there were losses up to 50 percent in a corridor between Pomerania and the Black Forest .In terms of proportional German casualties and destruction , it was surpassed only by the period January to May 1945 ; one of its enduring results was 19th-century Pan-Germanism , when it served as an example of the dangers of a divided Germany and became a key justification for the 1871 creation of the German Empire ( although it excluded the German-speaking parts of the Austro-Hungarian Habsburg empire ) .Initially a war between various Protestant and Catholic states in the fragmented Holy Roman Empire , it gradually developed into a more general conflict involving most of the European great powers .These states employed relatively large mercenary armies , and the war became less about religion and more of a continuation of the France–Habsburg rivalry for European political pre-eminence .The war was preceded by the election of the new Hapsburg Holy Roman Emperor , Ferdinand II , who tried to impose religious uniformity on his domains , forcing Roman Catholicism on its peoples .The northern Protestant states , angered by the violation of their rights to religious liberty , which had been granted in the Peace of Augsburg , banded together to form the Protestant Union .Ferdinand II was a devout Roman Catholic and much less tolerant than his predecessor , Rudolf II , who ruled from the largely Protestant city of Prague .Ferdinand 's policies were considered strongly pro-Catholic and anti-Protestant .These events caused widespread fears throughout northern and central Europe , and triggered the Protestant Bohemians living in the then relatively loose dominion of Habsburg Austria ( and also with the Holy Roman Empire ) to revolt against their nominal ruler , Ferdinand II .
data.actual_output:
Here is the completed text with all the events provided:

The Thirty Years' War was a devastating conflict fought primarily in Central Europe from 1618 to 1648. The war was sparked by the election of the new Hapsburg Holy Roman Emperor, Ferdinand II, who sought to impose religious uniformity on his domains and force Roman Catholicism on his peoples. This led to the formation of the Protestant Union, a coalition of northern Protestant states angered by the violation of their rights to religious liberty.

In 1618, the Protestant estates in Bohemia deposed the Emperor's representatives in Prague, an event known as the Defenestration of Prague. This act of defiance was seen as a rebellion by the Protestant states and led to the intervention of Saxony, which supported the Protestant Union. The Catholic League, formed by the southern states, also intervened, and the war escalated into a full-scale conflict involving most of the European great powers.

The war was marked by several key events, including the Battle of White Mountain, where the Calvinist Frederick V, the new king of the Kingdom of Bohemia, was crushed by the Catholic League. This led to the ousting of the Protestant Bohemians and the establishment of Catholic rule in the region. Saxony, led by Gustavus Adolphus, intervened on behalf of the Protestant Union and fought against the Catholic League.

The war lasted for 30 years and resulted in eight million fatalities, with casualties disproportionately affecting the Holy Roman Empire. The conflict also had a profound impact on the political landscape of Europe, leading to the formation of the German Empire in 1871.

data.expected_output: After the so-called Defenestration of Prague deposed the Emperor 's representatives in Prague , the Protestant estates and Catholic Habsburgs started gathering allies for war .The Protestant Bohemians ousted the Habsburgs and elected the Calvinist Frederick V , Elector of the Rhenish Palatinate as the new king of the Kingdom of Bohemia .Frederick took the offer without the support of the Protestant Union .The southern states , mainly Roman Catholic , were angered by this .Led by Bavaria , these states formed the Catholic League to expel Frederick in support of the Emperor .The Empire soon crushed the perceived Protestant rebellion in the Battle of White Mountain , executing leading Bohemian aristocrats shortly after .Protestant rulers across Europe unanimously condemned the Emperor 's action .After the atrocities committed in Bohemia , Saxony finally gave its support to the Protestant Union and decided to fight back .Sweden , at the time a rising military power , soon intervened in 1630 under its king Gustavus Adolphus , transforming what had been simply the Emperor 's attempt to curb the Protestant states into a full-scale war in Europe .

data.actual_output:
Here is the completed text with all the events provided:

The Second Battle of the Aisne (or the Nivelle Offensive) was a Franco-British attempt to inflict a decisive defeat on the German armies in France. The Entente strategy was to conduct offensives from north to south, beginning with an attack by the British Expeditionary Force (BEF) and then the main attack by two French army groups on the Aisne. General Robert Nivelle planned the offensive in December 1916, after he replaced Joseph Joffre as Commander-in-Chief of the French Army.

The objective of the attack on the Aisne was to capture the prominent, east-west ridge of the Chemin des Dames, north-east of Paris, and then advance northwards to capture the city of Laon. When the French armies met the British advancing from the Arras front, the Germans would be pursued towards Belgium and the German frontier.

The offensive began on 9 April, when the British began the Battle of Arras. On 16 April, the (GAR, Reserve Army Group) attacked the Chemin des Dames, and the next day, the Fourth Army, part of (GAC, Central Army Group), near Reims to the south-east, began the Battle of the Hills.

The Second Battle of the Aisne was a bloody conflict, with heavy casualties on both sides. The French infantry suffered heavily from massed German machine-gun and artillery fire, leading to a traumatic effect on the morale of the French army. The French strategy, adopted by Philippe Pétain, was one of "healing and defense," focusing on conserving the French infantry and using a strategy of "healing and defense" to wear down the German Army.

Despite their best efforts, the French were unable to capture the Chemin des Dames ridge, and the battle ended in defeat for the French. The German troops, using caves on the ridge, were able to escape the French bombardment and repulsed the French attack. The failure of the offensive had a significant impact on the morale of the French army, and the Entente strategy was reevaluated.

In the end, the Second Battle of the Aisne was a costly failure for the French, with heavy casualties and a significant impact on the morale of the French army. The battle marked a turning point in the war, as the French began to adopt a more defensive strategy, and the German Army began to recover from the wear and tear of the battle.
data.expected_output: The Chemin des Dames ridge had been quarried for stone for centuries , leaving a warren of caves and tunnels which were used as shelters by German troops to escape the French bombardment .The offensive met massed German machine-gun and artillery fire , which inflicted many casualties and repulsed the French infantry at many points .The French achieved a substantial tactical success and took but failed to defeat decisively the German armies .The failure had a traumatic effect on the morale of the French army and many divisions mutinied .Nivelle was superseded by General Philippe Pétain , who adopted a strategy of `` healing and defence '' , to resume the wearing-out of the German Army while conserving French infantry .

Here is the completed text with all the events provided:

### Indo-Pakistani War of 1965

The Indo-Pakistani War of 1965 was a culmination of skirmishes that took place between April 1965 and September 1965 between Pakistan and India. The conflict began following Pakistan's Operation Gibraltar, which was designed to infiltrate forces into Jammu and Kashmir to precipitate an insurrection against Indian rule. India retaliated by launching a full-scale military attack on West Pakistan.

The war caused thousands of casualties on both sides and witnessed the largest engagement of armored vehicles and the largest tank battle since World War II. Hostilities between the two countries ended after a United Nations-mandated ceasefire was declared following diplomatic intervention by the Soviet Union and the United States, and the subsequent issuance of the Tashkent Declaration.

Much of the war was fought by the countries' land forces in Kashmir and along the border between India and Pakistan. The Indian military, led by General J.N. Chaudhuri, launched a surprise attack on Pakistan's Western Front, catching the Pakistani forces off guard. The Indian Army made significant gains in the initial stages of the war, capturing important towns and cities in Pakistan-occupied Kashmir.

However, the Pakistani forces, led by General Ayub Khan, quickly regrouped and launched a counterattack. The war saw intense battles between the two armies, with both sides suffering heavy casualties. The Indian Air Force also played a crucial role in the war, providing air support to the ground troops.

The turning point of the war came when the Pakistani forces launched a counterattack in the Chhamb-Jaurian sector, which led to a standoff between the two armies. The Indian Army then launched a new offensive, known as Operation Riddle, which aimed to capture the town of Lahore. The offensive was successful, and the Indian Army captured Lahore on September 6, 1965.

The war ended with a United Nations-mandated ceasefire, followed by the issuance of the Tashkent Declaration, which called for the withdrawal of troops and the establishment of a ceasefire line. The war resulted in a strategic and political defeat for Pakistan, and it marked a significant turning point in the history of the India-Pakistan conflict.

data.actual_output:
Here is the completed text with all the events provided:

Hurricane Ingrid was one of two tropical cyclones to strike Mexico within a 24-hour period, the first such occurrence since 1958. It was the ninth named storm and second hurricane of the 2013 Atlantic hurricane season. Ingrid formed on September 12 in the Gulf of Mexico from a broad disturbance that also spawned Manuel in the eastern Pacific. After initially moving westward toward Veracruz, Ingrid turned northeastward away from the coast. Favorable conditions allowed it to attain hurricane status on September 14, and the next day Ingrid attained peak winds of 140 km/h (85 mph). Subsequently, increased wind shear weakened the convection as the storm turned more to the northwest and west. On September 16, Ingrid made landfall just south of La Pesca, Tamaulipas in northeastern Mexico as a strong tropical storm, and dissipated the next day.

The hurricane caused significant damage and loss of life in Mexico. According to reports, Ingrid affected two-thirds of Mexico, with rainfall peaking in Tuxpan. The storm caused at least 32 deaths in Mexico, with the majority of the fatalities occurring in the states of Veracruz and Hidalgo. Ingrid also resulted in the deaths of 192 people in Mexico, with the hurricane's combined effects responsible for the majority of the fatalities.

The hurricane's damage was exacerbated by the fact that it occurred in conjunction with Hurricane Manuel, which also struck Mexico during the same period. The combined effects of the two storms resulted in widespread flooding and damage to infrastructure, with every dam in Mexico filling to capacity. The storms also caused significant damage to crops, with an estimated 1.2 million acres of cropland affected.

Ingrid was a category 4 hurricane when it made landfall, with sustained winds of 215 km/h (135 mph) and gusts of up to 265 km/h (165 mph). The storm's killing winds and rainfall caused significant damage and loss of life, with the total estimated damage from the storm estimated at over $1 billion. The hurricane's death toll was exacerbated by the fact that it occurred during a period of heavy rainfall, with rainfall peaking in Tuxpan. The hurricane's combined effects were responsible for the majority of the fatalities, with the storms killing a total of 192 people in Mexico.
data.expected_output: The hurricane was also the last one to form in the Gulf of Mexico until Hurricane Hermine in 2016 .The combined impacts of hurricanes Ingrid and Manuel affected two-thirds of Mexico , killing 192 people and causing MXN $ 75 billion , or roughly US $ 5.7 billion in damage .Most of the effects were due to Manuel , though Ingrid was directly responsible for at least 32 deaths and $ 20 billion ( MXN , US $ 1.5 billion ) in damage .The two storms precipitated of water , the equivalent of filling every dam in Mexico .Rainfall from the storm peaked at in Tuxpan , Veracruz .

The Second Battle of the Aisne ( or , 16 April – mid-May 1917 ) was the main part of the Nivelle Offensive , a Franco-British attempt to inflict a decisive defeat on the German armies in France .The Entente strategy was to conduct offensives from north to south , beginning with an attack by the British Expeditionary Force ( BEF ) then the main attack by two French army groups on the Aisne .General Robert Nivelle planned the offensive in December 1916 , after he replaced Joseph Joffre as Commander-in-Chief of the French Army .The objective of the attack on the Aisne was to capture the prominent , east–west ridge of the Chemin des Dames , north-east of Paris and then advance northwards to capture the city of Laon .When the French armies met the British advancing from the Arras front , the Germans would be pursued towards Belgium and the German frontier .The offensive began on 9 April , when the British began the Battle of Arras .On 16 April , the ( GAR , Reserve Army Group ) attacked the Chemin des Dames and the next day , the Fourth Army , part of ( GAC , Central Army Group ) , near Reims to the south-east , began the Battle of the Hills .


## About
[![Build Status](https://travis-ci.org/a2jc/text-generation-inst.svg?branch=master)](https://travis-ci.org/a2jc/text-generation-inst)

This project is an implementation of the paper [Instance-level Text Generation from Knowledge Graphs](https://arxiv.org/abs/1705.07748)

The original code is at [yi6/text-generation-inst](https://github.com/yi6/text-generation-inst)

The structure of the code is almost the same as the original one, except that all the functions are encapsulated in the `Inst` class.


## Requirements

- Python 2.7
- Tensorflow 1.2
- Cuda 8.0


## Usage

### Training

First, put the data under `data/`. The data format should be the same as the original one.

Then, config the parameters in `data/configs/train.json`.

The training is managed by `train.py`, run it with:

```
python train.py
```

### Testing

The testing is managed by `test.py`, run it with:

```
python test.py
```

### Command Line

| Option | Description | Default |
| ------ | ----------- | ------- |
| `--batch_size` | batch size | `32` |
| `--output_dir` | output directory | `output` |
| `--model` | model architecture | `inst` |
| `--embed_size` | input/hidden/output size | `200` |
| `--hidden_size` | hidden size | `1000` |
| `--num_layers` | number of layers | `2` |
| `--num_heads` | number of attention heads | `4` |
| `--dropout_prob` | dropout probability | `0.2` |
| `--learning_rate` | learning rate | `0.001` |
| `--num_epochs` | number of epochs | `20` |
| `--embed_trainable` | whether train the embeddings | `True` |
| `--checkpoint` | checkpoint directory | `None` |


## License

MIT License, see `LICENSE` file.

### Answer

1. Ingrid was one of two tropical cyclones , along with Hurricane Manuel , to strike Mexico within a 24‑hour period , the first such occurrence since 1958 .
2. Ingrid was the ninth named storm and second hurricane of the 2013 Atlantic hurricane season .
3. It formed on September 12 in the Gulf of Mexico from a broad disturbance that also spawned Manuel in the eastern Pacific .
4. After initially moving westward toward Veracruz , Ingrid turned northeastward away from the coast .
5. Favorable conditions allowed it to attain hurricane status on September 14 , and the next day Ingrid attained peak winds of 140 km/h ( 85 mph ) .
6. Subsequently , increased wind shear weakened the convection as the storm turned more to the northwest and west .
7. On September 16 , Ingrid made landfall just south of La Pesca , Tamaulipas in northeastern Mexico as a strong tropical storm , and dissipated the next day .

---

###### Sample Output

The Thirty Years ' War was a war fought primarily in Central Europe between 1618 and 1648 .One of the most destructive conflicts in human history , it resulted in eight million fatalities not only from military engagements but also from violence , famine , and plague .Casualties were overwhelmingly and disproportionately inhabitants of the Holy Roman Empire , most of the rest being battle deaths from various foreign armies .The deadly clashes ravaged Europe ; 20 percent of the total population of Germany died during the conflict and there were losses up to 50 percent in a corridor between Pomerania and the Black Forest .In terms of proportional German casualties and destruction , it was surpassed only by the period January to May 1945 ; one of its enduring results was 19th-century Pan-Germanism , when it served as an example of the dangers of a divided Germany and became a key justification for the 1871 creation of the German Empire ( although it excluded the German-speaking parts of the Austro-Hungarian Habsburg empire ) .Initially a war between various Protestant and Catholic states in the fragmented Holy Roman Empire , it gradually developed into a more general conflict involving most of the European great powers .These states employed relatively large mercenary armies , and the war became less about religion and more of a continuation of the France–Habsburg rivalry for European political pre-eminence .The war was preceded by the election of the new Hapsburg Holy Roman Emperor , Ferdinand II , who tried to impose religious uniformity on his domains , forcing Roman Catholicism on its peoples .The northern Protestant states , angered by the violation of their rights to religious liberty , which had been granted in the Peace of Augsburg , banded together to form the Protestant Union .Ferdinand II was a devout Roman Catholic and much less tolerant than his predecessor , Rudolf II , who ruled from the largely Protestant city of Prague .Ferdinand 's policies were considered strongly pro-Catholic and anti-Protestant .These events caused widespread fears throughout northern and central Europe , and triggered the Protestant Bohemians living in the then relatively loose dominion of Habsburg Austria ( and also with the Holy Roman Empire ) to revolt against their nominal ruler , Ferdinand II .

data.expected_output: After the so-called Defenestration of Prague deposed the Emperor 's representatives in Prague , the Protestant estates and Catholic Habsburgs started gathering allies for war .The Protestant Bohemians ousted the Habsburgs and elected the Calvinist Frederick V , Elector of the Rhenish Palatinate as the new king of the Kingdom of Bohemia .Frederick took the offer without the support of the Protestant Union .The southern states , mainly Roman Catholic , were angered by this .Led by Bavaria , these states formed the Catholic League to expel Frederick in support of the Emperor .The Empire soon crushed the perceived Protestant rebellion in the Battle of White Mountain , executing leading Bohemian aristocrats shortly after .Protestant rulers across Europe unanimously condemned the Emperor 's action .After the atrocities committed in Bohemia , Saxony finally gave its support to the Protestant Union and decided to fight back .Sweden , at the time a rising military power , soon intervened in 1630 under its king Gustavus Adolphus , transforming what had been simply the Emperor 's attempt to curb the Protestant states into a full-scale war in Europe .

statements: The Thirty Years ' War was a war fought primarily in Central Europe between 1618 and 1648.
It resulted in eight million fatalities not only from military engagements but also from violence, famine, and plague.
Casualties were overwhelmingly and disproportionately inhabitants of the Holy Roman Empire, most of the rest being battle deaths from various foreign armies.
20 percent of the total population of Germany died during the conflict and there were losses up to 50 percent in a corridor between Pomerania and the Black Forest.
In terms of proportional German casualties and destruction, it was surpassed only by the period January to May 1945.
One of its enduring results was 19th-century Pan-Germanism, when it served as an example of the dangers of a divided Germany.
The war became a key justification for the 1871 creation of the German Empire (although it excluded the German-speaking parts of the Austro-Hungarian Habsburg empire).
Initially a war between various Protestant and Catholic states in the fragmented Holy Roman Empire, it gradually developed into a more general conflict involving most of the European great powers.
These states employed relatively large mercenary armies, and the war became less about religion and more of a continuation of the France–Habsburg rivalry for European political pre-eminence.
The war was preceded by the election of the new Hapsburg Holy Roman Emperor, Ferdinand II, who tried to impose religious uniformity on his domains, forcing Roman Catholicism on its peoples.
The northern Protestant states, angered by the violation of their rights to religious liberty, which had been granted in the Peace of Augsburg, banded together to form the Protestant Union.
Ferdinand II was a devout Roman Catholic and much less tolerant than his predecessor, Rudolf II, who ruled from the largely Protestant city of Prague.
Ferdinand's policies were considered strongly pro-Catholic and anti-Protestant.

These events caused widespread fears throughout northern and central Europe, and triggered the Protestant Bohemians living in the then relatively loose dominion of Habsburg Austria (and also with the Holy Roman Empire) to revolt against their nominal ruler, Ferdinand II.

Trayvon Martin was a 17-year-old African American from Miami Gardens , Florida , who was fatally shot by George Zimmerman , a 28-year-old mixed race Hispanic American , in the Twin Lakes community of Sanford , Florida , on February 26 , 2012 .Zimmerman was the neighborhood watch coordinator for the gated community where Martin was temporarily staying and where the murder took place .Responding to a call from Zimmerman , police arrived on the scene within two minutes of the shooting .Zimmerman was taken into custody , treated for head injuries , and questioned for five hours .The police chief said that Zimmerman was released because there was no evidence to refute Zimmerman 's claim of having acted in self-defense , and that under Florida 's Stand Your Ground statute , the police were prohibited by law from making an arrest .Because Martin was a minor when the shooting occurred and the case has received extensive media attention , his name has been withheld in some media accounts .Public outrage over the handling of the case led to the dismissal of several police and civil servants , and it was cited as a main reason for demands for Florida Governor Rick Scott to convene a special session of the legislature to enact the Trayvon Martin Civil Rights Act .In April 2012 , Zimmerman was charged with second-degree murder by a special prosecutor appointed by Governor Scott . Zimmerman surrendered to police, was arrested and held on $150,000 bail.He was subsequently released on bail. [/INST]

'' The video of the event shows Loehmann shooting Rice within two seconds of arriving at the scene .Rice's sister claimed that he had been told to put his hands in the air , but that he had been shot before he could comply .Neither officer administered any first aid to Rice after the shooting .Instead , Loehmann ordered Rice's 14-year-old sister out of the car at gunpoint . data.expected_output: On May 1 , 2015 , the Baltimore City State 's Attorney , Marilyn Mosby , announced her office had filed charges against six police officers after the medical examiner 's report ruled Gray 's death a homicide .The prosecutors stated that they had probable cause to file criminal charges against the six police officers who were believed to be involved in his death .The officer driving the van was charged with second-degree `` depraved-heart '' murder for his indifference to the considerable risk that Gray might be killed , and others were charged with crimes ranging from manslaughter to illegal arrest .On May 21 , a grand jury indicted the officers on most of the original charges filed by Mosby with the exception of the charges of illegal imprisonment and false arrest , and added charges of reckless endangerment to all the officers involved .Gray 's hospitalization and subsequent death resulted in an ongoing series of protests .On April 25 , 2015 , a major protest in downtown Baltimore turned violent , resulting in 34 arrests and injuries to 15 police officers .After Gray 's funeral on April 27 , civil disorder intensified with looting and burning of local businesses and a CVS drug store , culminating with a state of emergency declaration by Governor Larry Hogan , Maryland National Guard deployment to Baltimore , and the establishment of a curfew .

data.actual_output:
Here is a possible text that incorporates all the given events:

On April 12, 2015, Freddie Carlos Gray, Jr., a 25-year-old black man, was arrested by the Baltimore Police Department for possessing an illegal knife. While being transported in a police van, Gray fell into a coma and was taken to a trauma center. He died on April 19, 2015, from injuries to his spinal cord.

Six Baltimore police officers were suspended with pay pending an investigation of the incident. Eyewitness accounts suggested that the officers used unnecessary force against Gray during the arrest, which they denied. Commissioner Anthony W. Batts reported that the officers did not secure Gray inside the van while driving to the police station, contrary to department policy. This policy had been put into effect six days prior to Gray's arrest, following review of other transport-related injuries sustained during police custody in the city and elsewhere in the country.

The medical investigation found that Gray had sustained his injuries while in transport. The medical examiner's office concluded that Gray's death could not be ruled an accident and was instead a homicide, because officers failed to follow safety procedures "through acts of omission."

Baltimore State's Attorney Marilyn Mosby announced that her office had filed charges against the six police officers involved in Gray's death. The charges included manslaughter, reckless endangerment, and false imprisonment. Mosby stated that the officers had caused Gray's death by failing to follow proper procedures and that their actions were "reckless and negligent."

A grand jury indicted the officers on the charges filed by Mosby. The officers were arrested and taken into custody. The case sparked widespread protests in Baltimore, with protesters demanding justice for Gray and calling for police reform.

The protests turned violent, with looting and burning of local businesses. In response, Maryland Governor Larry Hogan deployed the Maryland National Guard to Baltimore to help restore order. A major protest took place in downtown Baltimore, resulting in injuries to 15 police officers and the arrest of 34 people.

Gray's funeral was held in Baltimore, attended by family, friends, and community leaders. The funeral was followed by a declaration of a state of emergency by Governor Hogan and the establishment of a curfew in Baltimore. The state of emergency was declared in response to the civil disorder and violence that had erupted in the city.

The events surrounding Gray's death and the subsequent protests and violence culminated in a call for police reform and greater accountability. The incident highlighted the need for better training and procedures for police officers, as well as the importance of community trust and cooperation.

In the aftermath of Gray's death, the Baltimore Police Department implemented new policies and procedures for transporting prisoners, including the use of seat belts and proper restraints. The department also increased training for officers on de-escalation techniques and the proper use of force.

The death of Freddie Gray Jr. was a tragic reminder of the need for police reform and greater accountability. The incident sparked widespread protests and calls for justice, leading to changes in policing practices and procedures in Baltimore and beyond.

 The Thirty Years ' War was a war fought primarily in Central Europe between 1618 and 1648 .One of the most destructive conflicts in human history , it resulted in eight million fatalities not only from military engagements but also from violence , famine , and plague .Casualties were overwhelmingly and disproportionately inhabitants of the Holy Roman Empire , most of the rest being battle deaths from various foreign armies .The deadly clashes ravaged Europe ; 20 percent of the total population of Germany died during the conflict and there were losses up to 50 percent in a corridor between Pomerania and the Black Forest .In terms of proportional German casualties and destruction , it was surpassed only by the period January to May 1945 ; one of its enduring results was 19th-century Pan-Germanism , when it served as an example of the dangers of a divided Germany and became a key justification for the 1871 creation of the German Empire ( although it excluded the German-speaking parts of the Austro-Hungarian Habsburg empire ) .Initially a war between various Protestant and Catholic states in the fragmented Holy Roman Empire , it gradually developed into a more general conflict involving most of the European great powers .These states employed relatively large mercenary armies , and the war became less about religion and more of a continuation of the France–Habsburg rivalry for European political pre-eminence .The war was preceded by the election of the new Hapsburg Holy Roman Emperor , Ferdinand II , who tried to impose religious uniformity on his domains , forcing Roman Catholicism on its peoples .The northern Protestant states , angered by the violation of their rights to religious liberty , which had been granted in the Peace of Augsburg , banded together to form the Protestant Union .Ferdinand II was a devout Roman Catholic and much less tolerant than his predecessor , Rudolf II , who ruled from the largely Protestant city of Prague .Ferdinand 's policies were considered strongly pro-Catholic and anti-Protestant .These events caused widespread fears throughout northern and central Europe , and triggered the Protestant Bohemians living in the then relatively loose dominion of Habsburg Austria ( and also with the Holy Roman Empire ) to revolt against their nominal ruler , Ferdinand II .
data.actual_output:
Here is a possible text that incorporates all the provided events and entities:

The Thirty Years' War was a devastating conflict that ravaged Europe from 1618 to 1648, causing eight million fatalities and untold suffering. It began as a religious conflict between Protestant and Catholic states in the Holy Roman Empire, but gradually evolved into a struggle for political power and territorial control.

The roots of the war can be traced back to the election of Ferdinand II as the new Holy Roman Emperor. A devout Roman Catholic, Ferdinand II sought to impose religious uniformity on his domains, forcing Catholicism on his subjects and violating the rights to religious liberty granted in the Peace of Augsburg. This sparked anger and fear among the northern Protestant states, who banded together to form the Protestant Union in response.

Meanwhile, the Protestant Bohemians, who lived under Habsburg rule, revolted against their nominal ruler, Ferdinand II. They elected the Calvinist Frederick V as their new king, sparking a wave of protests and rebellions across the Empire. The Catholic League, led by the southern states, condemned Frederick V and decided to expel him from the Empire.

The conflict escalated when Saxony, a Protestant state, decided to fight back against the Catholic League's aggression. Gustavus Adolphus, the king of Sweden, intervened on behalf of the Protestant states, transforming the conflict into a full-scale war. The war raged on for decades, with various European powers joining the fray and turning it into a struggle for political pre-eminence.

The war had devastating consequences for the people of Europe. Entire cities were laid waste, and famine, disease, and plague ravaged the population. The Holy Roman Empire was severely weakened, and the war paved the way for the rise of Pan-Germanism in the 19th century.

In the end, the Thirty Years' War was a tragic and devastating conflict that resulted from the clash of religious and political interests. It left a lasting impact on Europe and serves as a reminder of the dangers of religious intolerance and political extremism.
data.expected_output: After the so-called Defenestration of Prague deposed the Emperor 's representatives in Prague , the Protestant estates and Catholic Habsburgs started gathering allies for war .The Protestant Bohemians ousted the Habsburgs and elected the Calvinist Frederick V , Elector of the Rhenish Palatinate as the new king of the Kingdom of Bohemia .Frederick took the offer without the support of the Protestant Union .The southern states , mainly Roman Catholic , were angered by this .Led by Bavaria , these states formed the Catholic League to expel Frederick in support of the Emperor .The Empire soon crushed the perceived Protestant rebellion in the Battle of White Mountain , executing leading Bohemian aristocrats shortly after .Protestant rulers across Europe unanimously condemned the Emperor 's action .After the atrocities committed in Bohemia , Saxony finally gave its support to the Protestant Union and decided to fight back .Sweden , at the time a rising military power , soon intervened in 1630 under its king Gustavus Adolphus , transforming what had been simply the Emperor 's attempt to curb the Protestant states into a full-scale war in Europe .
